CHRISTINE CUBBOP(ph) (Caller): My name is Christine Cubbop.
I'm calling from Hawaii Island.
This Thanksgiving, I'm wanting to thank Angel Pilago.
I'm recovering from the nonstop demands of his grassroots campaign.
He ran for mayor on our island.
We didn't win, but the experience presented me with a personal first.
I woke up one morning so exhausted, I couldn't open my eyes.
I think everyone should have the chance to be so totally inspired, the chance to devote themselves to some goal and to give it absolutely everything they have.
Win or lose, it's a beautiful experience.
Thanks, Angel.
Ms.
CLAIRE MOXIN(ph) (Caller): My name is Claire Moxin, and I live in Van Meter, Iowa.
And this year I would like to thank my co-worker Jim Hunter(ph).
Earlier this year, he and his family were moving from Iowa to Colorado, and they were looking for a home for their flock of chickens, as well as a small herd of seven Nubian goats.
We acquired Jim's chickens and goats, and we just love the goats and chickens.
We love the joy that they've brought to our lives.
And they're not only a great source of eggs and hopefully milk soon, but they're also free stress relief.
Ms.
MADELINE BAKER(ph) (Caller): My name is Madeline Baker.
I live in Durham, North Carolina.
And this year I'd like to thank my sister-in-law Ann(ph).
Ann was a lifesaver during my wedding this summer.
She arranged and coordinated all the music, and she helped clean up after the last guest left.
Ms.
MOLLY FULLER(ph) (Caller): I'm Molly Fuller.
I live in San Francisco, California, and I'd like to thank my boyfriend, Steven Gibbs(ph).
He organized my rather small closet.
He made all my shoes fit.
I was sure there wasn't room for them.
He separated my pants, my shirts, my skirts, and he used those plastic separators so they all stay in their place.
We live in a what we call a ""loftominium,"" and it only has one closet, mine.
So, thank you, Steven.
Happy Thanksgiving.
And finally, along with the messages of thanks for kind acts, there was this story, born in tragedy.
Last month CIA Director Porter Goss told a Senate Committee that these intelligence leaks threaten U.S.
security, and he promised to take action.
Celery - salary.
Ms.
STEPHANIE SAMARA-HAMBLIN(ph) (Caller): This is Stephanie Samara-Hamblin from Gainesville, Florida.
It was a hell of a year.
My parents were in a single vehicle accident.
My father was killed instantly.

It seems strange to dwell on who I'm thankful for, but I find there's so many that I owe a debt of gratitude, and I don't even know all their names: the state trooper who couldn't legally tell me that my father was dead, but knew that I had to know; the nurse who held my mother as I told her over the phone that her husband of 52 years was gone; a myriad of nurses, techs, and therapists who got my mom, literally, back on her feet.
But my grand prize of thanks - my mom, Betty J.

Samara(ph), who could have given up, who wanted to give up at one point, but who through sheer grit and determination relearned how to walk, survived the loss of her husband, and taught me the truth of what a steel magnolia can be.
Thanks to all our listeners who sent us their thanks on this holiday.
ROBERT SIEGEL, host.
President-elect Barack Obama has cleared the way for his successor in the U.S.
Senate by resigning his seat early.
That's ahead of next week's lame-duck session.
In a statement today, Senator Obama said serving four years in the Senate had been one of the highest honors and privileges of his life.
His successor will be named by Illinois' Democratic governor, Rod Blagojevich.
Under state law, the governor's appointee will serve two years, wrapping up Senator Obama's turn.
And joining us now to talk about this is NPR White House correspondent Don Gonyea.
So, Don, he didn't really have to make it official at this point.
Why now?
Well - and again, no surprise whatsoever.
He's got another job to fall back on.
Right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But, you know, with that special session coming next week, it's hard to see how it would have been anything but awkward for him to be there.
Awkward to be there, but also awkward to not be there, because they are going to be discussing some very weighty things in that lame-duck session.
It's not necessarily the case where his vote would be critical to anything, but what happens by leaving now, we have at least six, possibly more, because there are some Senate races from...
Where they're still counting, yes.
From Election Day where they're still counting.
But at least six freshmen Democrats coming into the Senate.
If this new Illinois Senator replacing Senator Obama gets sworn in an hour, a day, a week, whatever it is...
There's seniority there.
According to the traditions and rules of the Senate, seniority really counts.
So this can give Illinois - an Illinois senator a leg up.
So that is probably the, you know, the main reason for doing it now.
Any word at all from Governor Blagojevich about his choice?
No.
But we do know it is his choice.
He could appoint himself, though he has told us he would not appoint himself.
We should also add that he is under investigation, and it might not be the most popular choice if he picked himself.
He has said he would do it by the end of the year, but also the fact that this is happening now does lead us to believe that perhaps he does have someone in mind.
He has not been the most popular man in Illinois in recent years.
But he should have a lot of friends now, at least the ones who'd like to get that appointment from him.
My guess is he's getting some phone calls and...
(Unintelligible) possibilities.
Yeah, and this person will serve.
There won't be a special election at any point.
So this is a really meaningful...
Two years in the U.S.
Senate.
It's two years in the U.S.
Senate.
One of the things he will be looking at, though, no doubt, is looking for a person who can win and hold onto this seat for the Democrats in a statewide election in 2010.
But some of the names - we do know that Senator Obama's close adviser and friend Valerie Jarrett, an African-American woman, has said she is not interested.
Not interested.
So we assume she's going to the White House, some sort of job there.
The - I was going to say the Reverend - but Representative Jesse Jackson, Jr., the son of...
The son of Reverend Jackson.
...Reverend Jackson has been actively campaigning for this.
The question is can he win statewide office?
Illinois' state Senate president, Emil Jones, 73 years old, Senator Obama's mentor, would be seen as a possibility.
But he would probably be a caretaker.
And then it's wide open to election in two years.
And a Republican could grab the seat at that point.
U.S.
Representative Jan Schakowsky, her name is mentioned.
Illinois Attorney General Lisa Madigan.
Here's an interesting one, Iraq war veteran Tammy Duckworth.
She was a former candidate for the House.
She now heads the Illinois Department of Veterans Affairs.
All over the newspapers this week, she laid a wreath at a veterans' memorial with Senator Obama.
Any word on when Senator Joe Biden will resign from his seat?
We have not heard.
There is no truth to the rumor that he's trying to figure out how to hold on to that Senate seat that he has held virtually his entire life.
He's going to miss the Senate.
He has told us that.
We haven't heard yet.
OK.
NPR White House correspondent Don Gonyea.
Thanks, Don.
My pleasure.
From primary schools to universities, educators are scrambling to add Chinese language programs to their curriculum.
And as Marjorie Sun reports, they are running into a big problem.
Jung Nai Fung(ph) is a Mandarin teacher at San Francisco's private Chinese American International School.
She is getting this ethnically diverse group of third graders ready to discuss the city's 1906 earthquake.
(Foreign language Spoken)
Mandarin teachers like Jung are in high demand these days, but they are in short supply.
Michael Levine is an education expert at the Asia society.
He says if five percent of high school students will be taking Mandarin nine years from nowâ€¦
We would need between 5,000 and 7,000 Chinese language teachers.
We are only at about 10 percent capacity right now.
We need to ramp up quickly.
Now you know how these puns work - groan.
It is my aim and it is my hope that we will witness a grand jury investigation with reporters present being asked to reveal who is leaking this information.
Reporter Dan Eggen has been covering this story for the Washington Post, and he joins us now.
Welcome to the program.
Nice to be here.
It sounds like the Justice Department is gathering evidence for that Grand Jury probe.
Yeah, and probably for more than one.
There are a number of different cases going on.

One is the reporting by the New York Times in December in which they revealed the existence of a surveillance program run by the National Security Agency monitoring phone calls in and out of the United States without warrants.
And the second was reporting by the Washington Post detailing a network of secret prisons run by the C.I.A.
around the world.
And then there's also, there's even a case that no one seems to have noticed out in Sacramento where reporters have actually already been at least contacted by F.B.I.
agents.
Who have F.B.I.
agents been talking to so far?
So far it's government employees.
Except for that Sacramento case, they always start these investigations by combing through the government officials that may have had access to information about the programs in question.
What kind of charges are we talking about here?
